elements.content: A series of supramolecular transformation cascades are presented here, employing ligand exchange reactions, concentration-dependent Borromean ring (BR) linking and unlinking, and inverse electron-demand Diels–Alder (IEDDA) reactions. The new family of template-free, tetrazine-edged BRs are constructed by using ligand exchange reactions, and their concentration-dependent linking and unlinking reactions have been observed. Moreover, Borromean precursors have been demonstrated to further undergo supramolecular structural transformations induced by rapid and efficient IEDDA reactions to afford corresponding post-assembly modified architectures. Remarkably, subtle steric increases of the pyridazine fragments obtained by IEDDA reactions is regarded to induce controlled topological transformations in the cascade, unlinking the Borromean structures by using electron-rich dienophiles as triggering signals.
elements.clean_text: A series of supramolecular transformation cascades are presented here, employing ligand exchange reactions, concentration-dependent Borromean ring (BR) linking and unlinking, and inverse electron-demand Diels-Alder (IEDDA) reactions. The new family of template-free, tetrazine-edged BRs are constructed by using ligand exchange reactions, and their concentration-dependent linking and unlinking reactions have been observed. Moreover, Borromean precursors have been demonstrated to further undergo supramolecular structural transformations induced by rapid and efficient IEDDA reactions to afford corresponding post-assembly modified architectures. Remarkably, subtle steric increases of the pyridazine fragments obtained by IEDDA reactions is regarded to induce controlled topological transformations in the cascade, unlinking the Borromean structures by using electron-rich dienophiles as triggering signals.

elements.content: Coordination-driven bottom-up approaches are now well-established in the construction of a range of aesthetically pleasing supramolecular structures. Taking advantage of the dynamic and reversible nature of metal–ligand coordination, supramolecular transformation serves as another powerful approach to generate diverse metallo­supra­molecular architectures with additional specific functions. Moreover, the disassembly and reassembly processes of the building blocks open up new insights to endow such “smart” structures allosteric regulation responding to the external stimuli.
elements.clean_text: Coordination-driven bottom-up approaches are now well-established in the construction of a range of aesthetically pleasing supramolecular structures. Taking advantage of the dynamic and reversible nature of metal-ligand coordination, supramolecular transformation serves as another powerful approach to generate diverse metallosupramolecular architectures with additional specific functions. Moreover, the disassembly and reassembly processes of the building blocks open up new insights to endow such "smart" structures allosteric regulation responding to the external stimuli.

elements.content: Molecular Borromean rings (BRs), a kind of topologically fascinating interlocked architectures, have drawn increasing attention for their topological aesthetics and also their potential applications. To realize this functionality and responsiveness, the selective construction and controllable transformation of BRs play pivotal roles. Meanwhile, solution-based post-assembly modification (PAM), which has been regarded as a useful tool to reveal the full potential of discrete supramolecular coordination architectures in terms of late-stage derivatization, has been rarely investigated on such intricate Borromean topologies.
elements.clean_text: Molecular Borromean rings (BRs), a kind of topologically fascinating interlocked architectures, have drawn increasing attention for their topological aesthetics and also their potential applications. To realize this functionality and responsiveness, the selective construction and controllable transformation of BRs play pivotal roles. Meanwhile, solution-based post-assembly modification (PAM), which has been regarded as a useful tool to reveal the full potential of discrete supramolecular coordination architectures in terms of late-stage derivatization, has been rarely investigated on such intricate Borromean topologies.

elements.content: Compatible PAM reactions employed to modify such architectures should not interfere with the fragile metal–ligand coordination holding supramolecular structures together but ideally should proceed quantitatively under mild conditions without lengthy purification processes. Taking advantage of the efficient construction of desired products under mild conditions with minimal generation of undesirable byproducts, the so-called inverse electron-demand Diels–Alder (IEDDA) reaction between electron-rich dienophiles and electron-deficient tetrazines has been regarded as a promising PAM reaction for application to discrete supra­molecular coordination complexes without tedious purification steps.
elements.clean_text: Compatible PAM reactions employed to modify such architectures should not interfere with the fragile metal-ligand coordination holding supramolecular structures together but ideally should proceed quantitatively under mild conditions without lengthy purification processes. Taking advantage of the efficient construction of desired products under mild conditions with minimal generation of undesirable byproducts, the so-called inverse electron-demand Diels-Alder (IEDDA) reaction between electron-rich dienophiles and electron-deficient tetrazines has been regarded as a promising PAM reaction for application to discrete supramolecular coordination complexes without tedious purification steps.

elements.content: Herein, by utilizing ligand exchange reactions, a series of rationally designed BRs containing potentially reactive tetrazine sites are obtained from accessible chloro-bridged macrocycles. Taking advantage of the IEDDA reaction between these tetrazine moieties and electron-rich dienophiles, covalent PAM has been developed to realize topological unlinking transformations from BRs to the corresponding component monomers.
elements.clean_text: Herein, by utilizing ligand exchange reactions, a series of rationally designed BRs containing potentially reactive tetrazine sites are obtained from accessible chloro-bridged macrocycles. Taking advantage of the IEDDA reaction between these tetrazine moieties and electron-rich dienophiles, covalent PAM has been developed to realize topological unlinking transformations from BRs to the corresponding component monomers.

elements.content: To verify the potential of using IEDDA reactions as a general approach for the rapid and facile modification of supramolecular complexes, this reaction was carried out on tetranuclear complex 1, prepared simply by subcomponent self-assembly of organometallic binuclear fragment [Cp*RhCl­(OTf)]2 with ligand 3,6-bis­(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4,5-tetrazine (BPTZ) in high yield (93.1%). NMR spectra were consistent with the expected rectangular symmetry, and the HR-ESI-MS data of 1 in CH3CN shows a peak at 932.0153 m/z assigned to [1 – 2OTf]2+. Moreover, a single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis unambiguously confirmed the rectangular structure of 1 in the solid state with a separation between tetrazine moieties of 3.6 Å (a).
elements.clean_text: To verify the potential of using IEDDA reactions as a general approach for the rapid and facile modification of supramolecular complexes, this reaction was carried out on tetranuclear complex 1, prepared simply by subcomponent self-assembly of organometallic binuclear fragment [Cp*RhCl(OTf)]2 with ligand 3,6-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4,5-tetrazine (BPTZ) in high yield (93.1%). NMR spectra were consistent with the expected rectangular symmetry, and the HR-ESI-MS data of 1 in CH3CN shows a peak at 932.0153 m/z assigned to [1 - 2OTf]2+. Moreover, a single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis unambiguously confirmed the rectangular structure of 1 in the solid state with a separation between tetrazine moieties of 3.6 Å (a).

elements.content: Top: Single-crystal X-ray structures of cations of (a) tetranuclear complex 1 and (b) modified macrocycle 2. Bottom: Scheme of an IEDDA reaction converting the tetrazine-edged macrocycle 1 to the pyridazine-edged complex 2.
elements.clean_text: 1  Top: Single-crystal X-ray structures of cations of (a) tetranuclear complex 1 and (b) modified macrocycle 2. Bottom: Scheme of an IEDDA reaction converting the tetrazine-edged macrocycle 1 to the pyridazine-edged complex 2.

elements.content: As a proof of this concept, the reactivity of rectangular complex 1 was demonstrated by using common Diels–Alder reagent 2,5-norbornadiene (NBD), which generally reacts with tetrazines, expelling 1 equiv of the relatively benign cyclopentadiene and nitrogen (as shown in Scheme S1 in the Supporting Information (SI)). The reaction between 1 and NBD (2 equiv per tetrazine) in acetonitrile solution resulted in a significant color change from scarlet to light yellow, while the clean formation of the modified macrocyclic complex 2 was verified by NMR and ESI-MS after 6 h at 298 K. It is noteworthy that the conversion of tetranuclear complex 1 to 2 occurs cleanly and without degradation of the assembled complex.
elements.clean_text: As a proof of this concept, the reactivity of rectangular complex 1 was demonstrated by using common Diels-Alder reagent 2,5-norbornadiene (NBD), which generally reacts with tetrazines, expelling 1 equiv of the relatively benign cyclopentadiene and nitrogen (as shown in Scheme S1 in the Supporting Information (SI)). The reaction between 1 and NBD (2 equiv per tetrazine) in acetonitrile solution resulted in a significant color change from scarlet to light yellow, while the clean formation of the modified macrocyclic complex 2 was verified by NMR and ESI-MS after 6 h at 298 K. It is noteworthy that the conversion of tetranuclear complex 1 to 2 occurs cleanly and without degradation of the assembled complex.

elements.content: Moreover, the versatility of the tetranuclear complex 1 was further exploited by soaking crystals of 1 with an excess of 2,5-norbornadiene in diethyl ether in a sealed vessel. The extent of conversion was confirmed to be satisfactory (>90%) by NMR analysis of the modified products after the soaked crystals were rinsed with ether to remove unreacted 2,5-norbornadiene guests after 1 week. The PAM process was also observed directly through a gradual color change from red to light yellow, corresponding to the degradation of the intensely colored tetrazine units (as shown in Figure S39 in the SI). For detailed structural comparison with 1, single-crystal XRD analysis data were collected on modified complex 2, revealing an analogous rectangular structure, but constructed with pyridazine edge ligands (b).
elements.clean_text: Moreover, the versatility of the tetranuclear complex 1 was further exploited by soaking crystals of 1 with an excess of 2,5-norbornadiene in diethyl ether in a sealed vessel. The extent of conversion was confirmed to be satisfactory (>90%) by NMR analysis of the modified products after the soaked crystals were rinsed with ether to remove unreacted 2,5-norbornadiene guests after 1 week. The PAM process was also observed directly through a gradual color change from red to light yellow, corresponding to the degradation of the intensely colored tetrazine units (as shown in Figure S39 in the SI). For detailed structural comparison with 1, single-crystal XRD analysis data were collected on modified complex 2, revealing an analogous rectangular structure, but constructed with pyridazine edge ligands (b).

elements.content: In light of the encouraging PAM reaction of simple tetranuclear complex 1, IEDDA reactions were envisaged to be employed after a ligand exchange reaction to compose a post-assembly modification cascade, giving a range of more intricate products from chloro-bridged complex 1, as shown in . In the ligand exchange step, the separation between the 3,6-bis­(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4,5-tetrazine ligand can be rationally increased by using the longer naphthazarin-based fragment (L 1 ) to replace the chloro bridges, creating the Borromean structure complex 3-BR. Stirring complex 1 with 2 equiv of Na2 L 1 in acetonitrile resulted in a clear, dark green filtrate. The neat 1H NMR spectrum of the low-concentration solution (1.0 mM) clearly indicated the self-assembly of molecular rectangle 3-MONO (see Figures S22 and S23 in the SI). Upon increasing the reaction concentration to 2.0 mM, new peaks were observed, along with peaks from 3-MONO in the 1H NMR spectrum that indicated the formation of a new compound. This observation propelled us to carry out reactions in CD3CN in various concentrations from 0.5 to 10 mM. The reaction carried out at 10 mM led to almost complete disappearance of the original signal of 3-MONO. A 1H diffusion ordered spectroscopy (DOSY) NMR spectrum of a mixture of 3 (5 mM) in CD3CN also confirmed the NMR signals associated with two diffusion coefficients, namely D = 4.93 × 10–10 m2/s for the monomeric ring and 3.99 × 10–10 m2/s for the new signals, indicating the generation of more advanced structures.

In the ligand exchange step, the separation between the 3,6-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4,5-tetrazine ligand can be rationally increased by using the longer naphthazarin-based fragment (L  1 ) to replace the chloro bridges, creating the Borromean structure complex 3-BR. Stirring complex 1 with 2 equiv of Na2 L  1  in acetonitrile resulted in a clear, dark green filtrate. The neat 1H NMR spectrum of the low-concentration solution (1.0 mM) clearly indicated the self-assembly of molecular rectangle 3-MONO (see Figures S22 and S23 in the SI). Upon increasing the reaction concentration to 2.0 mM, new peaks were observed, along with peaks from 3-MONO in the 1H NMR spectrum that indicated the formation of a new compound. This observation propelled us to carry out reactions in CD3CN in various concentrations from 0.5 to 10 mM. The reaction carried out at 10 mM led to almost complete disappearance of the original signal of 3-MONO. A 1H diffusion ordered spectroscopy (DOSY) NMR spectrum of a mixture of 3 (5 mM) in CD3CN also confirmed the NMR signals associated with two diffusion coefficients, namely D = 4.93 × 10-10 m2/s for the monomeric ring and 3.99 × 10-10 m2/s for the new signals, indicating the generation of more advanced structures.

elements.content:
Most hydrogen atoms, anions, solvent molecules, and disorder are omitted for clarity, N, blue; O, red; C, gray; Rh, violet.

Single-crystal XRD analysis has confirmed the Borromean structure of 3-BR in the solid state shown in b. As expected, the topologically intricate BRs obtained consist of three mechanically interpenetrating but chemically equivalent rings, each of them adopting a distorted rectangle-like conformation with an average length and width of 15.4 and 8.4 Å, respectively. The three distorted rectangles are held together by donor–acceptor stacking interactions (ca. 3.4 Å) between naphthazarin and electron-deficient tetrazine moieties, as evidenced from single-crystal XRD analysis (see Figure S33 in the SI).

a Most hydrogen atoms, anions, solvent molecules, and disorder are omitted for clarity, N, blue; O, red; C, gray; Rh, violet.  

Single-crystal XRD analysis has confirmed the Borromean structure of 3-BR in the solid state shown in b. As expected, the topologically intricate BRs obtained consist of three mechanically interpenetrating but chemically equivalent rings, each of them adopting a distorted rectangle-like conformation with an average length and width of 15.4 and 8.4 Å, respectively. The three distorted rectangles are held together by donor-acceptor stacking interactions (ca. 3.4 Å) between naphthazarin and electron-deficient tetrazine moieties, as evidenced from single-crystal XRD analysis (see Figure S33 in the SI).

elements.content: The success of the IEDDA reaction employed to modified Borromean ring 3-BR was verified by a shift in the 1H resonance for the pyridyl protons from 9.36, 7.94 ppm in 3-BR to 8.51, 8.17 ppm in 4 and the appearance of corresponding new proton resonances assigned to pyridazine at 8.18 ppm. As shown in , treating 3-BR with NBD in CD3CN at 10 mM resulted in almost quantitative formation of pyridazine-edged monomeric complex 4 after 12 h at 298 K, together with an equimolar quantity of cyclopentadiene. Furthermore, DOSY NMR spectroscopy of the modified products indicated a slightly smaller hydrodynamic radius than 3-BR, but a value almost identical to that of monomeric ring 3-MONO, confirming that the covalent PAM reaction induces transformations of BR structure 3-BR to generate the corresponding monomeric macrocycle 4.
elements.clean_text: The success of the IEDDA reaction employed to modified Borromean ring 3-BR was verified by a shift in the 1H resonance for the pyridyl protons from 9.36, 7.94 ppm in 3-BR to 8.51, 8.17 ppm in 4 and the appearance of corresponding new proton resonances assigned to pyridazine at 8.18 ppm. As shown in , treating 3-BR with NBD in CD3CN at 10 mM resulted in almost quantitative formation of pyridazine-edged monomeric complex 4 after 12 h at 298 K, together with an equimolar quantity of cyclopentadiene. Furthermore, DOSY NMR spectroscopy of the modified products indicated a slightly smaller hydrodynamic radius than 3-BR, but a value almost identical to that of monomeric ring 3-MONO, confirming that the covalent PAM reaction induces transformations of BR structure 3-BR to generate the corresponding monomeric macrocycle 4.

elements.content: (a) In situ 1H NMR monitoring (400 MHz, 298 K, CD3CN) of the reaction between Borromean ring 3-BR (10 mM) and NBD (2 equiv per tetrazine) to give modified macrocycle 4. (b) 1H NMR spectrum of 3-BR. (c–f) 1H NMR spectra of the reaction mixture of 3-BR and excess NBD at 0, 3.5, 5, and 12 h, respectively, revealing clean formation of 4 and cyclopentadiene after 12 h. Red circles denote NBD signals; purple triangles denote cyclopentadiene signals. (g) 1H DOSY spectrum of the reaction mixture after 12 h. Unit of D is m2/s.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) In situ 1H NMR monitoring (400 MHz, 298 K, CD3CN) of the reaction between Borromean ring 3-BR (10 mM) and NBD (2 equiv per tetrazine) to give modified macrocycle 4. (b) 1H NMR spectrum of 3-BR. (c-f) 1H NMR spectra of the reaction mixture of 3-BR and excess NBD at 0, 3.5, 5, and 12 h, respectively, revealing clean formation of 4 and cyclopentadiene after 12 h. Red circles denote NBD signals; purple triangles denote cyclopentadiene signals. (g) 1H DOSY spectrum of the reaction mixture after 12 h. Unit of D is m2/s.

elements.content: To further investigate the possibility of topological unlinking of BRs upon modification by IEDDA reactions, the lengthened proligand L 2 (K2Pd­(opba), opba = o-phenylene­bis­(oxamato)) was used in place of the naphthazarin fragment to further increase the separation between the parallel tetrazine ligands. Remarkably, the new Borromean structure 5 was obtained, as revealed by NMR spectroscopy, ESI-MS, and single-crystal XRD analysis. The 1H NMR spectrum of 5 is much more complex than that of normal metalla­rectangles, while all peaks between 6.47 and 9.16 ppm displayed a single diffusion constant of 3.55 × 10–10 m2/s, slightly smaller than that observed for 3-BR, in a DOSY NMR spectrum (SI, Figure S15), suggesting that they belong to a single species of larger size than 3-BR. The structure of 5 in solution was also supported by ESI-MS investigation, where the prominent peaks at m/z = 1489.1831 ([5 – 5OTf–]5+), 1898.7128 ([5 – 4OTf–]4+), and 2581.2666 ([5 – 3OTf–]3+) were in good agreement with their theoretical distribution (SI, Figures S27–S29). The X-ray crystal structure of 5 unambiguously confirmed its BR structure (), wherein each of the three equivalent rings adopts an inward concave rectangle with dimensions of 17.1 and 10.7 Å (Rh···Rh nonbonding distances). Intriguingly, a subsequent covalent PAM reaction of 5 engendered subtle configurational changes of the corresponding pyridazine-edged Borromean structure 6, which inherits a geometric construction similar to that of pre-modified BR 5, as shown in .
elements.clean_text: To further investigate the possibility of topological unlinking of BRs upon modification by IEDDA reactions, the lengthened proligand L  2  (K2Pd(opba), opba = o-phenylenebis(oxamato)) was used in place of the naphthazarin fragment to further increase the separation between the parallel tetrazine ligands. Remarkably, the new Borromean structure 5 was obtained, as revealed by NMR spectroscopy, ESI-MS, and single-crystal XRD analysis. The 1H NMR spectrum of 5 is much more complex than that of normal metallarectangles, while all peaks between 6.47 and 9.16 ppm displayed a single diffusion constant of 3.55 × 10-10 m2/s, slightly smaller than that observed for 3-BR, in a DOSY NMR spectrum (SI, Figure S15), suggesting that they belong to a single species of larger size than 3-BR. The structure of 5 in solution was also supported by ESI-MS investigation, where the prominent peaks at m/z = 1489.1831 ([5 - 5OTf-]5+), 1898.7128 ([5 - 4OTf-]4+), and 2581.2666 ([5 - 3OTf-]3+) were in good agreement with their theoretical distribution (SI, Figures S27-S29). The X-ray crystal structure of 5 unambiguously confirmed its BR structure (), wherein each of the three equivalent rings adopts an inward concave rectangle with dimensions of 17.1 and 10.7 Å (Rh⋅⋅⋅Rh nonbonding distances). Intriguingly, a subsequent covalent PAM reaction of 5 engendered subtle configurational changes of the corresponding pyridazine-edged Borromean structure 6, which inherits a geometric construction similar to that of pre-modified BR 5, as shown in .

elements.content: (a) Self-assembly of Borromean ring 5 and its modification, giving pyridazine-edged BR structure 6 by treatment with NBD. (b) Chemical structural representation of 5 and 6. (c) Solid-state structure of one component monomer of 6 for clarity (C, gray; N, blue; O, red; F, green; S, yellow; Rh, violet; Pd, orange). (d) Solid-state structure of modified BR 6 hosting a triflate anion inside its central cavity.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Self-assembly of Borromean ring 5 and its modification, giving pyridazine-edged BR structure 6 by treatment with NBD. (b) Chemical structural representation of 5 and 6. (c) Solid-state structure of one component monomer of 6 for clarity (C, gray; N, blue; O, red; F, green; S, yellow; Rh, violet; Pd, orange). (d) Solid-state structure of modified BR 6 hosting a triflate anion inside its central cavity.

elements.content: The BR based on the longer precursor L 2 retains its configuration as an inseparable ensemble made up by three interpenetrating but non-catenated rectangles after Diels–Alder PAM reactions with the electron-rich dienophile, while the same reaction induces structural transformations from BRs bridged by the naphthazarin fragment (L 1 ) to monomeric rings. Comparing the two different structures resulting from PAM reactions, the insufficient separation of the dipyridine ligands and increased steric hindrance of the post-modified pyridazine ligand in complex 3-BR are likely the determinants to trigger Borromean topological unlinking transformations. In the case of complex 5, a pair of dipyridine ligands pillared by L 2 is far enough apart to allow both the tetrazine or modified pyridazine ligands of another ring to thread between them; thus, the Borromean structures can form before and after the PAM reaction. By contrast, the distance between Rh centers linked by naphthazarin moieties is only 8.4 Å, which just allows the smaller pre-modified tetrazine to thread inside it, but not the pyridazine ring with its two additional hydrogen atoms, thus inhibiting the BR form.
elements.clean_text: The BR based on the longer precursor L  2  retains its configuration as an inseparable ensemble made up by three interpenetrating but non-catenated rectangles after Diels-Alder PAM reactions with the electron-rich dienophile, while the same reaction induces structural transformations from BRs bridged by the naphthazarin fragment (L  1 ) to monomeric rings. Comparing the two different structures resulting from PAM reactions, the insufficient separation of the dipyridine ligands and increased steric hindrance of the post-modified pyridazine ligand in complex 3-BR are likely the determinants to trigger Borromean topological unlinking transformations. In the case of complex 5, a pair of dipyridine ligands pillared by L  2  is far enough apart to allow both the tetrazine or modified pyridazine ligands of another ring to thread between them; thus, the Borromean structures can form before and after the PAM reaction. By contrast, the distance between Rh centers linked by naphthazarin moieties is only 8.4 Å, which just allows the smaller pre-modified tetrazine to thread inside it, but not the pyridazine ring with its two additional hydrogen atoms, thus inhibiting the BR form.

elements.content: Given these differences, the slight further reduction of the space between pre-modified dipyridine fragments, without increasing the steric hindrance via PAM reactions, was also predicted to block the formation of BRs. Thus, 2,5-dichloro-3,6-dihydroxy-p-benzoquinone (L 3 ), a similar but slightly shorter (0.4 Å) bridge ligand than L 1 , was strategically selected to test this hypothesis. As expected, the combination of L 3 and the tetrazine ligand afforded tetranuclear monomeric macrocycle 7, which was characterized by NMR and single-crystal XRD analysis. As shown in Figure S40 in the SI, compared with BR structure 3, wherein the narrow separation of dipyridine ligands is strained to its limit (8.6 Å) to allow another ligand to thread through it, the further decreased distance between the tetrazine ligands linked by the chloranilic acid no longer allows other tetrazine moieties through the macrocycle to form BRs.
elements.clean_text: Given these differences, the slight further reduction of the space between pre-modified dipyridine fragments, without increasing the steric hindrance via PAM reactions, was also predicted to block the formation of BRs. Thus, 2,5-dichloro-3,6-dihydroxy-p-benzoquinone (L  3 ), a similar but slightly shorter (0.4 Å) bridge ligand than L  1 , was strategically selected to test this hypothesis. As expected, the combination of L  3  and the tetrazine ligand afforded tetranuclear monomeric macrocycle 7, which was characterized by NMR and single-crystal XRD analysis. As shown in Figure S40 in the SI, compared with BR structure 3, wherein the narrow separation of dipyridine ligands is strained to its limit (8.6 Å) to allow another ligand to thread through it, the further decreased distance between the tetrazine ligands linked by the chloranilic acid no longer allows other tetrazine moieties through the macrocycle to form BRs.

elements.content: In conclusion, we present a series of supramolecular transformation cascades employing ligand exchange reactions, concentration-dependent Borromean ring linking and unlinking, and IEDDA reactions. As a proof-of-concept, the starting chloro-bridged tetranuclear macrocycle 1 has been demonstrated to undergo IEDDA reactions to form the corresponding pyridazine-edged complex 2 both in solution and in crystalline form. Accordingly, the verified PAM reaction, with NBD serving as external stimulus, was then further employed to trigger supramolecular transformation of Borromean ring structure 3-BR to obtain monomeric ring 4. By varying the separation of parallel tetrazine ligands, the increased steric hindrance of the modified pyridazine ligand is shown to be crucial to induce unlinking of the BR. We believe that a deeper understanding of supramolecular transformation cascades induced by PAM reactions will be helpful to construct bespoke architectures and responsive supramolecular systems, opening up new insights into the field of smart materials.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, we present a series of supramolecular transformation cascades employing ligand exchange reactions, concentration-dependent Borromean ring linking and unlinking, and IEDDA reactions. As a proof-of-concept, the starting chloro-bridged tetranuclear macrocycle 1 has been demonstrated to undergo IEDDA reactions to form the corresponding pyridazine-edged complex 2 both in solution and in crystalline form. Accordingly, the verified PAM reaction, with NBD serving as external stimulus, was then further employed to trigger supramolecular transformation of Borromean ring structure 3-BR to obtain monomeric ring 4. By varying the separation of parallel tetrazine ligands, the increased steric hindrance of the modified pyridazine ligand is shown to be crucial to induce unlinking of the BR. We believe that a deeper understanding of supramolecular transformation cascades induced by PAM reactions will be helpful to construct bespoke architectures and responsive supramolecular systems, opening up new insights into the field of smart materials.

cln_elements.content:
(a) Stimulus–Response Map Depicting the Major Products Expressed in the Supramolecular Transformation Cascades Employing Ligand Exchange Reactions, Concentration-Dependent Borromean Ring Linking and Unlinking, and IEDDA Reactions and (b) Structure of Cationic Borromean Ring <bold>3-BR</bold> in (Left) Chemical Structural Representation and (Middle) Skeleton Representation, and (Right) Solid-State Structure of One Component Ring of <bold>3-BR</bold> <xref ref-type="fn" rid="sch1-fn1"></xref>

Most hydrogen atoms, anions, solvent molecules, and disorder are omitted for clarity, N, blue; O, red; C, gray; Rh, violet.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Stimulus-Response Map Depicting the Major Products Expressed in the Supramolecular Transformation Cascades Employing Ligand Exchange Reactions, Concentration-Dependent Borromean Ring Linking and Unlinking, and IEDDA Reactions and (b) Structure of Cationic Borromean Ring 3-BR in (Left) Chemical Structural Representation and (Middle) Skeleton Representation, and (Right) Solid-State Structure of One Component Ring of 3-BR       a Most hydrogen atoms, anions, solvent molecules, and disorder are omitted for clarity, N, blue; O, red; C, gray; Rh, violet.

cln_elements.content: (a) In situ 1H NMR monitoring (400 MHz, 298 K, CD3CN) of the reaction between Borromean ring 3-BR (10 mM) and NBD (2 equiv per tetrazine) to give modified macrocycle 4. (b) 1H NMR spectrum of 3-BR. (c–f) 1H NMR spectra of the reaction mixture of 3-BR and excess NBD at 0, 3.5, 5, and 12 h, respectively, revealing clean formation of 4 and cyclopentadiene after 12 h. Red circles denote NBD signals; purple triangles denote cyclopentadiene signals. (g) 1H DOSY spectrum of the reaction mixture after 12 h. Unit of D is m2/s.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  (a) In situ 1H NMR monitoring (400 MHz, 298 K, CD3CN) of the reaction between Borromean ring 3-BR (10 mM) and NBD (2 equiv per tetrazine) to give modified macrocycle 4. (b) 1H NMR spectrum of 3-BR. (c-f) 1H NMR spectra of the reaction mixture of 3-BR and excess NBD at 0, 3.5, 5, and 12 h, respectively, revealing clean formation of 4 and cyclopentadiene after 12 h. Red circles denote NBD signals; purple triangles denote cyclopentadiene signals. (g) 1H DOSY spectrum of the reaction mixture after 12 h. Unit of D is m2/s.

cln_elements.content: (a) Self-assembly of Borromean ring 5 and its modification, giving pyridazine-edged BR structure 6 by treatment with NBD. (b) Chemical structural representation of 5 and 6. (c) Solid-state structure of one component monomer of 6 for clarity (C, gray; N, blue; O, red; F, green; S, yellow; Rh, violet; Pd, orange). (d) Solid-state structure of modified BR 6 hosting a triflate anion inside its central cavity.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Self-assembly of Borromean ring 5 and its modification, giving pyridazine-edged BR structure 6 by treatment with NBD. (b) Chemical structural representation of 5 and 6. (c) Solid-state structure of one component monomer of 6 for clarity (C, gray; N, blue; O, red; F, green; S, yellow; Rh, violet; Pd, orange). (d) Solid-state structure of modified BR 6 hosting a triflate anion inside its central cavity.

metadata.title:
Covalent
Post-assembly Modification Triggers Structural
Transformations of Borromean Rings
